item.title: DiffX - Next-Generation Extensible Diff Format
item.description: If you’re a software developer, you’ve probably worked with diff files. Git diffs, Subversion diffs, CVS diffs.. Some kind of diff. You probably haven’t given it a second thought, really. You make some changes, run a command, a diff comes out. Maybe you hand it to someone, or apply it elsewhere, or put it up for review.

item.title: How I improved my unit tests
item.description:
Hello, welcome to a new post!
Today I want to talk about a very important topic that should never be missing in serious software development: unit tests.
Unit tests are code we write to validate the logic of our program. These tests are characterized by evaluating small parts of the

item.title: Uniqueness for Behavioural Types · KC Sivaramakrishnan
Poker for Startup Founders
item.description: Poker and startups share more than late nights, caffeine, and the occasional bluff. Both worlds rely on decision making under uncertainty, calculated risks, and knowing when to fold and move on. So let's break down some poker jargon with a founder's twist.

item.title: The future of User Research - Jeremy Belcher
item.description: User research will need to adapt, and fast. But those who adapt will have an unfair advantage. Up until now, a core value of research has been to de-risk software development. When building is expensive, mistakes are costly, especially when they’re caught late. Getting smart up front via research leads to fewer mistakes down the... Continue reading →

item.title: UBI and the Environmental Cost of Overemployment
item.description: Imagine for a moment that we paused all economic growth. The pie isn’t getting bigger, but it isn’t getting smaller either. Now, imagine we invent an efficiency improvement—some new technology. This means the same amount of goods and services can be produced with less employment of natural resources.
